    currentDataset: {"id":"ngzmj4zkms","doi":{"id":"10.17632/ngzmj4zkms.1","status":"allocated","prefix":"10.17632","allocated":true},"name":"Data for: Human Gut Microbiota from  Autism Spectrum Disorder Promote Behavioral Symptoms in Mice","description":"Raw data (excluding raw sequencing and metabolomic data) used to construct figures for manuscript. Data is predominantly in csv or tsv format. qza and qzv files are QIIME2 outputs and can be viewed at https://view.qiime2.org/ . mat files are mat lab datasets.  \n\nHuman Gut Microbiota from Autism Spectrum Disorder Promote Behavioral Symptoms in Mice\n\nGil Sharon1,*, Nikki Jamie Cruz1, Dae-Wook Kang2,3,21, Michael J. Gandal4,5,6,7, Bo Wang1, Young-Mo Kim8, Erika M. Zink8, Cameron P. Casey8, Bryn C. Taylor9, Christianne J. Lane10, Lisa M. Bramer11, Nancy G. Isern8, David W. Hoyt8, Cecilia Noecker12, Michael J. Sweredoski1, Annie Moradian1, Elhanan Borenstein12,13,14,15,16, Janet K. Jansson8, Rob Knight17,18,19, Thomas O. Metz8, Carlos Lois1, Daniel H. Geschwind4,5,6, Rosa Krajmalnik-Brown2,3, and Sarkis K. Mazmanian1,20,*\n\nAutism spectrum disorder (ASD) manifests as alterations in complex human behaviors including social communication and stereotypies. In addition to genetic risks, the gut microbiome differs between typically-developing (TD) and ASD individuals, though it remains unclear whether the microbiome contributes to symptoms. We transplanted gut microbiota from human donors with ASD and TD controls into germ-free mice, and reveal that colonization with ASD microbiota was sufficient to induce hallmark autistic behaviors. The brains of mice colonized with ASD microbiota display alternative splicing of ASD-relevant genes. Microbiome and metabolome profiles of mice harboring human microbiota predict that specific bacterial taxa and their metabolites modulate ASD behaviors. Indeed, treatment of an ASD mouse model with candidate microbial metabolites improves behavioral abnormalities and affects neuronal excitability in the brain. We propose that the gut microbiome modulates behaviors in mice via production of neuroactive metabolites, suggesting that gut-brain connections contribute to the pathophysiology of ASD.","owner_id":"31349fae-689e-3593-9a96-21343610a00d","version":1,"publish_date":"2019-05-30T01:53:53.417Z","data_licence":{"id":"01d9c749-3c4d-4431-9df3-620b2dcfe144","short_name":"CC BY 4.0","full_name":"Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International","description":"This dataset is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International licence.\n\nWhat does this mean?\nYou can share, copy and modify this dataset so long as you give appropriate credit, provide a link to the CC BY license, and indicate if changes were made, but you may not do so in a way that suggests the rights holder has endorsed you or your use of the dataset. code can be used to unpack matlab data to a Pandas dataframe (Python 3):\n\nimport numpy as np\nfrom scipy.io import loadmat  # this is the SciPy module that loads mat-files\nimport pandas as pd\n\nmat = loadmat('caImaging_taurine 5AV.mat')  # load mat-file\nmdata = mat['RawData']  # Data variable in mat file\n\n# to get the data out of matlabs data structure, which is an array or arrays: \ni,j = mdata.shape\nAllCells = pd.DataFrame()\nfor column in range(j-1): # iterate over days\n    day = mdata[0,column+1].item()\n    group1_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[1,column+1]))\n    group1_data['DIV'] = day\n    group1_data['Treatment'] = mdata[1,0].item()\n    group1_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group1_data)+1)\n    group2_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[2,column+1]))\n    group2_data['DIV'] = day\n    group2_data['Treatment'] = mdata[2,0].item()\n    group2_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group2_data)+1)\n    group3_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[3,column+1]))\n    group3_data['DIV'] = day\n    group3_data['Treatment'] = mdata[3,0].item()\n    group3_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group3_data)+1)\n\n    AllCells = pd.concat([AllCells, group1_data, group2_data, group3_data])\nAllCells.set_index(['DIV','Treatment', 'counter'], inplace=True)\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells.stack().reset_index()\nAllCells_stacked.columns = ['DIV', 'Treatment','Cell#', 'Time', 'dF/F0']\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells_stacked[AllCells_stacked['dF/F0'] >= 0] data (excluding raw sequencing and metabolomic data) used to construct figures for manuscript. Data is predominantly in csv or tsv format. qza and qzv files are QIIME2 outputs and can be viewed at https://view.qiime2.org/ . mat files are mat lab datasets.</p>\n<p>Human Gut Microbiota from Autism Spectrum Disorder Promote Behavioral Symptoms in Mice</p>\n<p>Gil Sharon1,*, Nikki Jamie Cruz1, Dae-Wook Kang2,3,21, Michael J. Gandal4,5,6,7, Bo Wang1, Young-Mo Kim8, Erika M. Zink8, Cameron P. Casey8, Bryn C. Taylor9, Christianne J. Lane10, Lisa M. Bramer11, Nancy G. Isern8, David W. Hoyt8, Cecilia Noecker12, Michael J. Sweredoski1, Annie Moradian1, Elhanan Borenstein12,13,14,15,16, Janet K. Jansson8, Rob Knight17,18,19, Thomas O. Metz8, Carlos Lois1, Daniel H. Geschwind4,5,6, Rosa Krajmalnik-Brown2,3, and Sarkis K. Mazmanian1,20,*</p>\n<p>Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) manifests as alterations in complex human behaviors including social communication and stereotypies. In addition to genetic risks, the gut microbiome differs between typically-developing (TD) and ASD individuals, though it remains unclear whether the microbiome contributes to symptoms. We transplanted gut microbiota from human donors with ASD and TD controls into germ-free mice, and reveal that colonization with ASD microbiota was sufficient to induce hallmark autistic behaviors. The brains of mice colonized with ASD microbiota display alternative splicing of ASD-relevant genes. Microbiome and metabolome profiles of mice harboring human microbiota predict that specific bacterial taxa and their metabolites modulate ASD behaviors. Indeed, treatment of an ASD mouse model with candidate microbial metabolites improves behavioral abnormalities and affects neuronal excitability in the brain. We propose that the gut microbiome modulates behaviors in mice via production of neuroactive metabolites, suggesting that gut-brain connections contribute to the pathophysiology of ASD.</p>\n","methodHtml":"<p>The following python code can be used to unpack matlab data to a Pandas dataframe (Python 3):</p>\n<p>import numpy as np<br>\nfrom scipy.io import loadmat  # this is the SciPy module that loads mat-files<br>\nimport pandas as pd</p>\n<p>mat = loadmat('caImaging_taurine 5AV.mat')  # load mat-file<br>\nmdata = mat['RawData']  # Data variable in mat file</p>\n<p># to get the data out of matlabs data structure, which is an array or arrays:<br>\ni,j = mdata.shape<br>\nAllCells = pd.DataFrame()<br>\nfor column in range(j-1): # iterate over days<br>\nday = mdata[0,column+1].item()<br>\ngroup1_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[1,column+1]))<br>\ngroup1_data['DIV'] = day<br>\ngroup1_data['Treatment'] = mdata[1,0].item()<br>\ngroup1_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group1_data)+1)<br>\ngroup2_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[2,column+1]))<br>\ngroup2_data['DIV'] = day<br>\ngroup2_data['Treatment'] = mdata[2,0].item()<br>\ngroup2_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group2_data)+1)<br>\ngroup3_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[3,column+1]))<br>\ngroup3_data['DIV'] = day<br>\ngroup3_data['Treatment'] = mdata[3,0].item()<br>\ngroup3_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group3_data)+1)</p>\n<p>AllCells = pd.concat([AllCells, group1_data, group2_data, group3_data])<br>\nAllCells.set_index(['DIV','Treatment', 'counter'], inplace=True)<br>\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells.stack().reset_index()<br>\nAllCells_stacked.columns = ['DIV', 'Treatment','Cell#', 'Time', 'dF/F0']<br>\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells_stacked[AllCells_stacked['dF/F0'] >= 0]</p>\n","embargo_date_formatted":"30 May 2019","embargo_date_remaining":"5 days ago","embargo_date_formatted_long":"30 May 2019 at 12:00am UTC","embargo_date_formatted_YYYYMMDD":"2019-05-30","embargo_date_remaining_days":"-5 days","underEmbargo":false,"canSeeEmbargoedData":true,"downloadAll":true,"publish_date_formatted":"2019-05-30","hasFiles":true,"showLoadMore":true,"filesSize":853853827,"tooltips":{"title":{"text":"Give an accurate and descriptive title for your dataset, to help others find and understand your data. following python code can be used to unpack matlab data to a Pandas dataframe (Python 3):\\n\\nimport numpy as np\\nfrom scipy.io import loadmat  # this is the SciPy module that loads mat-files\\nimport pandas as pd\\n\\nmat = loadmat('caImaging_taurine 5AV.mat')  # load mat-file\\nmdata = mat['RawData']  # Data variable in mat file\\n\\n# to get the data out of matlabs data structure, which is an array or arrays: \\ni,j = mdata.shape\\nAllCells = pd.DataFrame()\\nfor column in range(j-1): # iterate over days\\n    day = mdata[0,column+1].item()\\n    group1_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[1,column+1]))\\n    group1_data['DIV'] = day\\n    group1_data['Treatment'] = mdata[1,0].item()\\n    group1_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group1_data)+1)\\n    group2_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[2,column+1]))\\n    group2_data['DIV'] = day\\n    group2_data['Treatment'] = mdata[2,0].item()\\n    group2_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group2_data)+1)\\n    group3_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[3,column+1]))\\n    group3_data['DIV'] = day\\n    group3_data['Treatment'] = mdata[3,0].item()\\n    group3_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group3_data)+1)\\n\\n    AllCells = pd.concat([AllCells, group1_data, group2_data, group3_data])\\nAllCells.set_index(['DIV','Treatment', 'counter'], inplace=True)\\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells.stack().reset_index()\\nAllCells_stacked.columns = ['DIV', 'Treatment','Cell#', 'Time', 'dF/F0']\\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells_stacked[AllCells_stacked['dF/F0'] >= 0] \\n\\n\",\"related_links\":[],\"size\":853853827,\"jsonFriendlyName\":\"Data for: Human Gut Microbiota from  Autism Spectrum Disorder Promote data (excluding raw sequencing and metabolomic data) used to construct figures for manuscript. Data is predominantly in csv or tsv format. qza and qzv files are QIIME2 outputs and can be viewed at https://view.qiime2.org/ . mat files are mat lab datasets.</p>\\n<p>Human Gut Microbiota from Autism Spectrum Disorder Promote Behavioral Symptoms in Mice</p>\\n<p>Gil Sharon1,*, Nikki Jamie Cruz1, Dae-Wook Kang2,3,21, Michael J. Gandal4,5,6,7, Bo Wang1, Young-Mo Kim8, Erika M. Zink8, Cameron P. Casey8, Bryn C. Taylor9, Christianne J. Lane10, Lisa M. Bramer11, Nancy G. Isern8, David W. Hoyt8, Cecilia Noecker12, Michael J. Sweredoski1, Annie Moradian1, Elhanan Borenstein12,13,14,15,16, Janet K. Jansson8, Rob Knight17,18,19, Thomas O. Metz8, Carlos Lois1, Daniel H. Geschwind4,5,6, Rosa Krajmalnik-Brown2,3, and Sarkis K. Mazmanian1,20,*</p>\\n<p>Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) manifests as alterations in complex human behaviors including social communication and stereotypies. In addition to genetic risks, the gut microbiome differs between typically-developing (TD) and ASD individuals, though it remains unclear whether the microbiome contributes to symptoms. We transplanted gut microbiota from human donors with ASD and TD controls into germ-free mice, and reveal that colonization with ASD microbiota was sufficient to induce hallmark autistic behaviors. The brains of mice colonized with ASD microbiota display alternative splicing of ASD-relevant genes. Microbiome and metabolome profiles of mice harboring human microbiota predict that specific bacterial taxa and their metabolites modulate ASD behaviors. Indeed, treatment of an ASD mouse model with candidate microbial metabolites improves behavioral abnormalities and affects neuronal excitability in the brain. We propose that the gut microbiome modulates behaviors in mice via production of neuroactive metabolites, suggesting that gut-brain connections contribute to the pathophysiology of ASD.</p>\\n\",\"methodHtml\":\"<p>The following python code can be used to unpack matlab data to a Pandas dataframe (Python 3):</p>\\n<p>import numpy as np<br>\\nfrom scipy.io import loadmat  # this is the SciPy module that loads mat-files<br>\\nimport pandas as pd</p>\\n<p>mat = loadmat('caImaging_taurine 5AV.mat')  # load mat-file<br>\\nmdata = mat['RawData']  # Data variable in mat file</p>\\n<p># to get the data out of matlabs data structure, which is an array or arrays:<br>\\ni,j = mdata.shape<br>\\nAllCells = pd.DataFrame()<br>\\nfor column in range(j-1): # iterate over days<br>\\nday = mdata[0,column+1].item()<br>\\ngroup1_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[1,column+1]))<br>\\ngroup1_data['DIV'] = day<br>\\ngroup1_data['Treatment'] = mdata[1,0].item()<br>\\ngroup1_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group1_data)+1)<br>\\ngroup2_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[2,column+1]))<br>\\ngroup2_data['DIV'] = day<br>\\ngroup2_data['Treatment'] = mdata[2,0].item()<br>\\ngroup2_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group2_data)+1)<br>\\ngroup3_data = pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(mdata[3,column+1]))<br>\\ngroup3_data['DIV'] = day<br>\\ngroup3_data['Treatment'] = mdata[3,0].item()<br>\\ngroup3_data['counter'] = range(1,len(group3_data)+1)</p>\\n<p>AllCells = pd.concat([AllCells, group1_data, group2_data, group3_data])<br>\\nAllCells.set_index(['DIV','Treatment', 'counter'], inplace=True)<br>\\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells.stack().reset_index()<br>\\nAllCells_stacked.columns = ['DIV', 'Treatment','Cell#', 'Time', 'dF/F0']<br>\\nAllCells_stacked = AllCells_stacked[AllCells_stacked['dF/F0'] >= 0]</p>\\n\",\"embargo_date_formatted\":\"30 May 2019\",\"embargo_date_remaining\":\"5 days ago\",\"embargo_date_formatted_long\":\"30 May 2019 at 12:00am UTC\",\"embargo_date_formatted_YYYYMMDD\":\"2019-05-30\",\"embargo_date_remaining_days\":\"-5 days\",\"underEmbargo\":false,\"canSeeEmbargoedData\":true,\"downloadAll\":true,\"publish_date_formatted\":\"2019-05-30\",\"hasFiles\":true,\"showLoadMore\":true,\"filesSize\":853853827,\"tooltips\":{\"title\":{\"text\":\"Give an accurate and descriptive title for your dataset, to help others find and understand your data.
